job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cortlandt Manor, NY
pros: Good benefits such as 401k and 4 weeks vacation.  I wish that I could think if something else nice to say but even the facility was not renovated to what staff would consider efficient because staff is never consulted on such matters even though we have to work in the environment.
cons: Unrealistic expectations and the favoritism is sickening.  The hard working employees are treated so unfairly while certain staff get away with murder.  There are too many chiefs and not enough Indians.  How can you have an assistant director and director but no supervisor or manager? Management contradicts themselves constantly and never give you the tools to get the job done.

job_title: Financial Advisor in New York, NY
pros: the hospital is very clean, organized, team work, i love the orientation and the training assistance I received and once I started working, they still helping with advice though any other issues.  The benefits and salaries are very good as well and they made the employee feel appreciate they they celebrate employee of the month and lunch, dinner and breakfast for the employees.  job security, work life, and balance.
cons: one part I didn't like is that basically not everyone in Presbyterian hospital is on the 1199 Union which makes us feel different than other employees and different benefits. the checks are  not 40hrs. and depends short breaks.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, no out of pocket expenses, and meet good friends along the way. Also Dr. Kelly trying to change the atmosphere despite the unqualified and poor management being hired or hooked by Human Resources.
cons: Poor management, Directors are clueless to what is going on in their department, and the politics that goes on with advancement. If you don't belong to a click , then moving up the ladder is out of the question. There are unqualified employees running a department because upper management likes them. The hospital is dysfunctional and unsafe for patient care starting with the Emergency Room which is filthy with a lack of empathy. Putting patients first should not be the hospital's slogan but running a plantation is.

job_title: EMS Paramedic in New York, NY
pros: I gave 3 stars because NYP is both good and bad. If you want a "job" and not a "career", this is the place for you. Compensation OK, but health benefits and a non-contributory pension are excellent.  Just don't have ideas or be inspired.
cons: Like other reviews I have to back up the nepotism claim. I'm year nearly 20 years and have gone absolutley NOWHERE despite outstanding evaluations every single year. I receive many accolades yet cannot get promoted. Why? I don't mingle with the right crowd. There is zero top-down management. Every unit/department is a fiefdom unto itself. The infighting is nauseating. Does this happen at Hopkins or the Mayo/Cleveland Clinics? I don't know, but doubt it.

job_title: Medical Technologist I in New York, NY
pros: Great staff on day shift.  Great 1199 benefits. Covered Education expense.  Management has improved somewhat since I've been here.
cons:
Retention rate of scientists is terrible. Someone is always leaving every 2 months or less. The salary has been going up slowly but not high enough for people to stay. People are still leaving while the salary increase is happening so what is that telling you....

Management piggy backs off holiday parties that the employees plan when management should be the ones planning and using their budget to plan parties for us. But their views are they give us overtime which is a "gift." So, they don't do anything else.  No, Its terrible scheduling on their part. 

Lab week is a joke here. Not that is a selling point for me but I can't stand that week because instead of feeling appreciated for the care we provide for patients ... Management has us solving riddles to win absolutely nothing

review_title: great company with excellent employee engagement and full benefits
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I've worked for many large hospitals throughout the nation and NYP is definitely one of the best.  Top leadership consistently strive to solicit feedback from employees (even at non-management level staff).  There are numerous employee events and services that are offered that help to create a better home/work balance for employees.  On top of that, the benefits packages are very favorable for new employees.
cons: Still a large academic medical center/hospital so with that comes a great deal of change, but slow change.  There are several "old-timer" employees who are a bit more resistant to change and feedback for improvement, but that comes with any workplace.  A lot of the technology used in the hospital is a bit outdated and the IT departments are quite resistant to feedback or improvement to streamline processes.

review_title: The Best Career Move I Ever Made
job_title: Programmer Analyst II in New York, NY
pros:
Great salary, benefits and work / life balance.
The hospitals desire to put patients first also mirrors what they want for their employees.
I love my team and the organizational structure.
There is room for growth since the organization is large and NYP keeps on taking on other hospitals.
2 day orientation at the Griffin Room at Cornell campus was beautiful.
Everyone I've met so from any department / campus was very professional.
cons:
The hiring process is lengthy. This isn't necessarily a con. It's just a big organization and NYP has many hospital affiliates / departments. Mine took about 2-3 weeks where others mentioned to me at orientation, it took months.
Since I came from a smaller company (70 employees), coming into a big organization (10,000+)  made me feel a bit overwhelmed because there are so many managers for different departments / campuses and the culture was different. However, NYP has various resources and tools available for new hires to get all the info they need with Infonet and company wide emails.

job_title: Ultrasound Technologist in New York, NY
pros: A company culture that prioritizes work-life balance, yields increased productivity and overall happiness in the workplace. Great people, professional environment, and always open-door opportunities are unlimited. Commitment is the key to success.
cons: Do not have such, at all.

review_title: A secure place to work, where helping others can sometimes be overshadowed by overwork and trivial details.
job_title: Bacteriology Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: Prestigious hospital and the opportunity to be a part of something that helps people.
cons: Endless "makework" in terms of self-assessments, multiple webinars (although good, they are incessant and the workload is already very high) and quizzes. Pay is not equivalent to similar positions elsewhere around the city.

review_title: Great Place to Work as an IT Professional
job_title: Multiple Positions in New York, NY
pros:
- Friendly staff and co-workers
- Great place to learn and grow inter-departmentally
- Benefits
- Salary grows with you
- Many opportunities for advancement
- Resources provided to learn and grow outside of the company (grants for school, accreditation, and more) 
- Programs offered for employees include help with diet and exercise, mental health and more
-
cons:
- Having to change in and out of protective wear around patients (understandably necessary though)
- Politics tend to slow down certain projects (that's life)
- Management can be an issue in certain departments. Things around us aren't always in control to help us do our jobs better.

job_title: IT Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Benefits. Culture is good on paper and words, but not applied in practice.
cons: Culture in IT is bureaucratic and environment is often not concerned with provided services or results, but the insecurities  of management. Often only secretarial type of IT employees who do not produce IT results and are technical  are promoted and valued.  The 'workers' not so much. Annual revues are used to put the producing employees down. Raises are always 2.5% no matter what and how much one has done. Only secretarial employees get bonuses and bigger raises. Complains to HR and higher up are not listened too, even if the whole group goes to complain.

job_title: Service Desk Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
- Movement within the company is very free. Options to move up in the company are often available. 
- Employees receive medical, dental, life, and retirement benefits.
cons:
- IT seems to have a culture of the lazier the better. 
- Management regularly rolls out new projects, applications, procedures, and systems without almost any planning leaving the projects to often fail or roll as smoothly as a Mack truck down a steep hill.
-Many people in IT management don't have an IT background so they don't understand the limitations. 
- Security only applies if you're not important enough. 
- HR is hard to reach.

review_title: Great experience depending on leadership and department
job_title: Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: The health benefits package is extremely competitive. Working for the number 1 hospital in NY definitely pays off in that regard. The college reimbursement program offered by the hospital (at the non-unioninzed campuses) is amazing. The company strongly promotes growth from within so you're constantly seeing turnover of staff (I myself started out as a Frontline  staff member). Some departments faster than other but turnover nonetheless. The NYP, as of the time of this review, has 10 campuses so you have many options in terms of location.
cons: Not every campus is created equal. Some have more overall cheer and are a pleasure to work in and some have processes that are extremely broken, are struggling to stay afloat, and want to take you along for the ride (after the second or so interview it might be worth asking for a tour so you can see the culture and condition of the hospital for your self).

job_title: Human Resources in New York, NY
pros:
1) The culture of respect. Everyone is treated respectfully no matter what job title or age.
2) The potential for growth. The organization encourages career growth laterally and vertically.
3) The vision of becoming No1 and collectively working towards it. Makes everyone feel valued to see that their work makes a difference.
cons:
1) Seniority system. No matter how much you prove your potential, you can only grow to the next level after certain years or sometimes decades.

2) Infrastructure development. I would look at one of the corporates offices, and due to poor chair quality, I like many other employees developed back pain for which I have to take regular treatment.

job_title: Instrument Technician in New York, NY
pros: Working with people here help make the job tolerable lots of laughs the manager and supervisor aren't bad neither.
cons: We are $10,000 under paid by the New York average yet the work keeps being added and now they want to add even more work.. it's too much and makes you feel slave like... unfortunately management doesn't feel it is but won't step in to help when things get out of hand and are causing other employees to look for other jobs elsewhere. Unfortunately I myself can't continue working here knowing I'm greatly under paid. 1199 union really doesn't care about your position and show little interest in any problems brought to there attention but takes your pay with no issues...

review_title: If your looking for a dream job here it is!
job_title: Staff Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Co-workers are wonderful, management are always there to address concerns and the benefits are great!! Senior nurses (especially night nurses) are very helpful to new nurses like myself in adjusting to this new field and they take us under their wing. Flexibility of work schedule makes it a bit easier to manage work and family life, especially during family emergencies. When there are issues, senior managment take the time to discuss it with you and follow up with you. Also, the emphasis on not only caring for the patient but also the family is an great message and is really incorperated into daily care.
cons: Staffing is organized by census and not by accuity level of the pateints on the floor making hard on occasion to manage work load, at least in the NICU where I work.  Besides that there really isn't anything I can think of.

review_title: NYP Weill Cornell: A Hospital That Puts Patients First, and Employees Last
job_title: CNA in New York, NY
pros: A big name, highly accredited hospital with major medical advancements. It boasts new technology that advances medical breakthroughs for people suffering from an array of diseases and cancer. It bends over backwards to please every patient.
cons: It bends over backwards to please every patient, even at the cost of bedside nurses. Often times leaves workers incredibly understaffed and overwhelmed; -most especially the general medicine floors with high acuity levels. There is also an increase of patients with mental disorders that staff are not always equipped to handle, and there is also a 24-hour visiting policy with patients families that can sometimes get in the way of care, and nurses and aides are left stranded to have to work "around" these issues, with not much help from management, or adequate security to assist.

review_title: You have to go in their focused and with a set goal or you will become trapped at one position.
job_title: Pateint Service Advocate in New York, NY
pros: Fair payscale, multiple job postings allowing lateral movement within the company, Very fair as far as days off to take care of family and vacation time.
cons: Very little upward movement once your at a position 90% chance your staying their until your fired, the only exception if you want to become a nurse. Middle management and lower management are below average and tend to be unprofessional and pety. Senior Management is excellent and weeds them out.

job_title: Veni-puncture Technician in New York, NY
pros:
The level you are expected to be at in your career is high yet they are will to train you well. There's an air of Independence amougst the team atmosphere that allows you to do what you were hired to do best with minimal distractions.

During training they really don't hold your hand. They get you on the unit floor gaining experience day 1 and you build up your confidence fast if you are someone that has never worked in a hospital before.
cons: The on boarding process is long and drawn out even in the covid 19 days especially the background check. It still took about 2 months for the full process. What's next in the on boarding process as well as the training process is never really clear or explained until you are actually at that step. I wish there was a more detailed list or explanation of what was to come but you obviously will get through it no problem if u can thrive in change.

job_title: Patient Navigator in New York, NY
pros: This place feels like home. People always have a smile on their faces and strive to be the best in their roles here at work. Everyone is as valuable as your coworker next to you no matter the title.
cons: Since this hospital is near the FDR drive public transportation isn't so accessible. Also traffic can be very hectic during the day.

review_title: great on paper, not in person
job_title: Staff RN in New York, NY
pros: Hospital name for resume purposes
cons: This hospital is extremely money driven and I find that they have difficulty know the difference between running a hospital and running a business. Decisions are based on the money being spent rather than the benefits the patients may receive. As stated they nickel and dime every item related to patient care without a second thought. Everyone states they care about the patients but only if they have money or can benefit the hospital in some way. Don't come here looking for compassionate overall patient care or team work among staff. I find this place disorganized in every aspect from bed coordination to pharmacy to staffing issues. Only people inside the facility who have never worked at another hospital find this place functional or tolerable.

job_title: Human Resources Professional in New York, NY
pros: NYP has done an amazing job supporting employees through COVID-19. Plenty of resources and leadership compassion. For clinical staff, managing through COVID brought out the worst in managers as it was as highly stressful environment. Many clinical personnel are traumatized. Some NYP locations are worse off than others in terms of ongoing employee support and staffing. Like a lot of companies, NYP is in bad financial shape/loss of revenue due to COVID. Open job reqs will not be filled so staffing resources will not be addressed anytime soon.
cons: Truly, for some in clinical roles and in administrative roles at hospitals or at the headquarters, life is great. they get challenging assignments, recognition, advancement opportunities, etc. For others, their leadership is scared, engages in backstabbing, promotes unqualified people with bad behavior due to politics I guess. Micromanaging and bureaucracy are part of the norm.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Union benefits (child care benefits, health insurance). Pay is competitive. Pension is a plus. When you punch out you are done working.
cons:
Columbia campus: Pay accuracy depends on timekeeper and often don’t get paid correctly (not to your advantage), oppressive environment, hard to get anything done, good ol boy network. Ancient technology, inability to get basic necessities to do job.  All about good PR but not about caring for patients, ie happy to send staff to Puerto Rico to help but NOT willing to accept patients for treatment here.
Backlash for standing up for yourself if something goes wrong is not right. It’s a very oppressive environment.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, competitive salary, meaningful career -- as an employee you are doing God's work regardless of how harsh the managerial environment was
cons:
Deep-rooted politics, no break times for long-hours' work. You will be retaliated against for seeking clarification in order to perform well. Manager in power will take this a sign of disobedience and tried everything to get rid of you. HR won't help you, they allied with manager to terminate you under false pretext. This is against corporate compliance and against law but it is allowed in this campus. 

You can be terminated for any or no reason within a short period of time without being given a fair chance to learn and perform well. No matter whom you talked to to get help -- recruiter, coworkers -- they were afraid and won't help you. 

It's a shame this happened in such a prestigious hospital. They have no respect for employees who put their faith in this organization and took a leap of faith in joining. Beware. If you are a follower and can give up your rights easily, perhaps you can survive.

review_title: Prestigious place to work, good benefits, average pay for a job with stability albeit very regimented atmosphere.
job_title: QA/QC OFFICER in New York, NY
pros: Great Hospital, like a small city with almost every amenity (albeit dated) on-site with anything else needed nearby. Work with many smart people. Hospital makes an attempt to appreciate employees (although the typical type event where a gargantuan handout of chinese made umbrellas that tear on first use might indicate the attempts are more symbolic than anything). And occasionally "Amazing Things Are Happening Here"...sometimes. Benefits are pretty good...with most folks getting 30 days off a year.
cons: Paperwork city. Understandable since its a hospital but the quizzes and training is repetitive and unending -- the endless IRB, patient safety, managment, fire safety, HIPAA, LIS, infectious disease, etc. eats up nearly one day a month. Employee reviews take too long to complete, favoritism is rife despite the union ranks.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Great and I mean GREAT Benefits.
On par salary with the rest of the hospitals.
Work/life
cons:
Career advancement. It is almost purely based on who you know. A good chunk of the team hired in the last year or two are relatives or has parents who are friends with the senior management. 

When a senior was planning to leave, no one in my current team was even told there would be a opening to fill until it was already filled.

Also, depending on the manager and department you get, your skills might NOT be transferable in any other area.

This is a great place if you are working in your final years or even mid career. I sincerely regret starting my career here.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Technologist in New York, NY
pros: Generous vacation and sick leave through 1199, shift differential for evening and night shifts. Will hire techs straight out of school before they know any better. There is usually a lot of overtime available because people leave constantly.
cons: Miserable working environment. Half of the coworkers are angry and resentful of the others. The pay is not very good, the training is not thorough, and the management is not committed to providing good care, only fast turnaround. There is a very heavy workload and continual short-staffing, and the turnover rate is very high because people are not happy here and leave as soon as something else is lined up. Some of the older workers bet on who will be the next person to leave. No upward mobility or feedback.

job_title: Nurses Aide in New York, NY
pros: Great location, facility, and environment. Nice, friendly, professional, team-oriented coworkers. Management and supervisors are respectful, especially if you are a good worker. Perks, training, benefits, security are excellent. Everyday you meet different people/patients/personalities which can be a positive experience based on how you look at it.  12 hour shifts are a plus : )
cons: Everyday is different and unpredictable which may bring more challenges in trying to put patients first.  No paid maternity leave. Hard work, yet rewarding.

review_title: Great place to work and grow
job_title: IT Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: NYP is a great place to work. There is a number of opportunities to grow as a professional and to develop further in the career path of choice here. Work is meaningful and mission driven, as the hospital values providing the best care for patients through excellent work processes and technology. Senior leadership are incredibly competent and help lead initiatives that are high impact and high meaning.
cons: Work/life balance may be a challenge at times, especially for those in the business side of the hospital. As there are so many initiatives going on, it is not hard to fall into the trap of being a workaholic. There is an unspoken culture that promotes hard work and long hours, and while work is meaningful, work never ends and must be balanced.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
-I have the opportunity to work with some of the smartest, most innovative and driven people in the field; from the support staff to our doctors and nurses. 
-Having access to executive level discussions, I know that our senior team truly cares about our employees as people first and employees second.  They are always focused on creating a great overall environment for our employees. 
-We have the most brilliant, forward thinking and inspiring CEO I've ever had the pleasure to work with.  He continues to promote the importance of respect, teamwork, innovation, responsibility, excellence, and empathy because he believes that will allow us to provide the best experience for our patients and will allow us to continue growing as the best place to work.
cons: There aren't any cons that are worth mentioning.  I can't imaging working anywhere else.

review_title: I am happy to be working for NYPH. Most of the people who I work with are happy to be working their as well.
job_title: Cardia Care in New York, NY
pros: Working for NYPH Is great. I have been working their for 9 years now. I have a month off every year with roll over in case I don't want to go vacation. 12 sick days a year that also rolls over if i don't get sick and 4 personal days every year. Not to mention if I work a holiday I get time and a half and a day off with pay. The benefits are great. Most of that is thanks to my union Local 1199
cons: The work load can be high some days. I thinks its due to being in new york city. Some days we don't have enough coverage for the demand.

review_title: Current nurse looking to be worn out
job_title: Registered Nurse in Flushing, NY
pros: Pay and benefits . You will definitely learn a lot , but you could get the same learning experience anywhere else .
cons: The nurse to patient ratio could be outrageous !!!! You could get up to 9 patients on any given day.  Management is very flawed . Also a lot of old nurses trying to eat the young and it's reinforced because nurse managers want to stay on these senior nurses' good side so they suck up to them. Nurses also have to chase after PAs to put in orders that shouldn't be reminded by nurses.  I'm staying only for the experience and slightly above the average compensation  . There's no parking either .

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Washington Heights, NY
pros: Major goal is to put patients first. Is very proactive in improving the environment and focusing on Patient Centered Care
cons: Staff members who have held same position for so long and have done nothing to upgrade themselves bring a lot of negative energy to the units. Managers' power taken away on some aspects from Union employees. They are able to get away with a lot of behavior that would never be tolerated at other major institutions

job_title: Staff RN in New York, NY
pros: The hospital has the best intentions to better itself and the care our patients receive. Compensation is adequate. I am frequently proud of the care my patients receive. The unit that I am currently on is very encouraging of  multidisciplinary decision making in our patient care.
cons: Frequent understaffing issues. Professionalism varies greatly in all levels of staff. Reasons behind decisions made by management are not always transparent. A good percentage of folks that work for the hospital and have direct patient care have no interest in doing their jobs. There is no weekend pay differential.

review_title: Temprorary - ok, long term- do not even think about it unless you are brainless.
job_title: Mental Health Worker in White Plains, NY
cons: administration is brainless; all they look at is numbers, yet, they get that part wrong as well! They are loosing so much money & they are putting every single employee at risk - employees gets hurt at least once a week (broken arm, leg, wrist, head injuries, bites, bruises, riots... you name it...). And when you get hurt, forget about help from the hospital, they will probably take you to court, before they pay anything! I do not understand how this place is still running, but I do not know a single employee there who enjoys their job!

review_title: Great place to work, but with a few exceptions to the rule.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great place to work, awesome benefits, great atmosphere, wonderful staff around the campuses. Amazing things are happening here.
cons: Occasionally, there will be those who pile on responsibilities outside of your job description with unexpected deadlines. Upper management tend to throw people under the bus when things go wrong, instead of owning their respective orders to employees. Communication between departments really need to improve. Newly hired managers with "experience" tend to take credit for others hard work and insight.

job_title: Staff RN in New York, NY
pros: Career growth is supported within the institution, tuition reimbursement, excellent human resources department.
cons: There are different hospitals that make up NYP so I can't speak for the organization as a whole. My experience at NYP Lower Manhattan Hospital was poor. It had the worst nursing culture I've ever seen, lacking in clinical knowledge and skill, professionalism, and teamwork. In addition management was totally unsupportive. The hospital was taken over by NYP a few years ago, it has a LONG way to go to live up to the NYP name.

review_title: All the pros are not worth the cons
job_title: Medical Secretary in New York, NY
pros:
1. enjoyable work, get to help patients understand their care. 
2. Work closely with doctors so you learn a lot. 
3. Strict 9-5, rarely have to stay overtime. 
4. Great health insurance benefits
cons:
1. Micromanagement to the max
2. loves the blame game, bullying, cliques 
3.  Inexperienced management 
4.  Extremely hierarchal 
5.  tense fear filled, anxious atmosphere

review_title: Fecal Management.  Needs Overall from main manhattan campus.
job_title: ACP in Queens Village, NY
pros: Money is great. I'm told to shut up because I'm well compensated.
cons: Fecal like management.  Poor leadership.  I was informed last year that I need to join the medical group of NYPQ and that nothing would change. Long and behold fecal changes. THe medical group has their own HR personnel who isnt really effiicient or new at her job. Things get " noted" but nothing gets done. Reimbursements take forever and everyone has a title but when asked to answer dedicated questions  pertaining to their titled role  , you hear crickets.  Employees of the medical group constantly have to chase these newly minted administrators down on emails you've sent 2 months ago.

job_title: Registrar in New York, NY
pros: This is a great place to work with great pay and benefits, however, the tenured employees are unhappy and tired of being in the same position for years and will make you feel like you chose the wrong place. Do not allow them to make you feel that way, until you see something wrong with your own 2 eyes do not pay mind to the office politics.
cons: The co-workers who have been in the same position on the same floor for 15 years plus. They are miserable and they let life pass them by so they are mad at themselves not you.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Health system stays competitive for salaries in the area. Some very good skilled professionals at the direct care level.
cons: At Lower Manhattan site, there are many challenges that seem forgivable/ tolerable at first but over time when the same issues are occurring it's difficult to overlook/function without getting what you need to get your job done. There are other locations that enjoy the perks of being  successful in the system but not Lower Manhattan site. Very difficult to endure the culture that had been a part of that hospital since it changed hands several years ago. Also, many departments behave in a very unprofessional manor and do things that are not consistent with the values of their professions.

job_title: RN, Bsn in New York, NY
pros: Good pay, benefits, coworkers, school compensation, discounts. Really great and interesting patients come here (oncology floor that is). You will learn a lot as the sickest patients come here to be treated.
cons: No management whatsoever, aiming for magnet but it's a doctor run hospital and will never reach magnet status as nurses views are not taken into account at all, complete lack of accountability, zero support for nurses, an absolute reactive institution instead of a proactive hospital, no teamwork, overall lack in communication in all healthcare disciplines. The hospital is running off the name and is not doing anything to back up its #1 position on the list as top hospital in New York.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Benefits & (some) perks. etc etc etc
cons: I have mixed feelings about my views as an employee. Like many other big american corporations this is a place to grow in many aspects (including a big thick skin!). Too many layers to navigate through. Being part of the union presents some pros & cons as well. They do their part and do it fairly well. As a member though it is not so much about your own contribution as it is about strength in affiliates number. In some higher hierarchy positions it is a highly competitive, fast-paced work environment so be ready for the rat-race. After all it is corporate America.

job_title: Med Tech in New York, NY
pros: It is the most prestigious hospital in the state of New York. It has a wonderful benefits package which includes 4 weeks paid vacation for new time employees. Everyone who works there seems happy and getting new equipment for departments is never a hassle. I however cannot say too much because I was just recently hired.
cons: Because it is such a good hospital if one day I wanted to leave to travel for a while, it would be difficult to be rehired because I would be one their "record." Because it is such a large hospital you become very specialized in one field and would be difficult to find a new job elsewhere.

review_title: Overall, a great place to work for with great people and great benefits.
job_title: Nursing Support in White Plains, NY
pros: Great benefits, including 403-b (no matching) and cash-balance pension plan (hospital contributes a specified percentage of your annual earnings). You will finds lots of knowledgeable people who often have worked there for years, if not decades. You are definitely rewarded for longevity.
cons: Limited advancement opportunities. The support positions often max out quickly, and non-professional staff have limited options. Sometimes transferring to another department to learn new skills can be difficult.

job_title: Customer Service in Cortlandt Manor, NY
pros: I enjoyed my job very much especially working with patients and ins. companies.Could not say enough about 90% of my fellow employees.
cons: The dept. I worked in the director, manager and supervisor show favoritism . The picked on other employees very much. Also had there own set of rules different from hospitals policies, They look the other way especially when one particular supervisor is on personal phone calls and her cell phone all day.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: benefits/vacation, great coworkers, decent pay
cons: no work life balance, tons of work, favoritism, horrible manager, director and VP (VP is a bulldozer), retaliation for challenging work flows, staff is always wrong and finally, the entire financial planning team is miserable.

review_title: Good place to work, if you're not in a dysfunctional department
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Good reputation for resume building; many brilliant and dedicated clinical staff (physicians, nurses, researchers); very diverse staff and patient population; opportunities to provide care for unusual conditions
cons: Poor compensation; disconnect between public relations/marketing and reality; entrenched dysfunctional departmental leadership; very inflexible, difficult middle-management within the departments and in hospital administration

job_title: Respiratory Care Practitioner in New York, NY
pros:
Great collaboration between nurses, PAs And ry
Great respect
RTs highly regarded and relied on for pt management
cons:
RT department management  only concerned about directives from upper management.

DO NOT WORK NIGHT HERE  unless your ok with compromising pt safety because it’s massively understaffed
Evaluations are BS no matter what you do the best you will get is meet standards because they are trying to save money.

No opportunity for advancement

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The compensation was decent for a hospital in New York City. In addition, the healthcare plan was spectacular, as well as the time off. We recieved 20 vacation days and 6 plus sick days.
cons: The company did not offer adequate training of specific programs. In addition, there was no job growth, managers were hired from outside the company (from companys such as Blue Cross) and they expected analyst to "do" the work and not "learn" or ask question. Perhaps, this was only the case in the group I worked.

job_title: Pharmacist in New York, NY
pros: Great working atmosphere, good team to work with. Salaries are competitive, union benefits are pretty good. Employee satisfaction is being surveyed every year, but nothing changes  as a result.
cons: Department management , when implementing changes , often does not take in consideration staff opinion who actually provide patient care. As a result  changes often not only not practical, but interfere with work. Not much space to grow, unless someone is interested to become a manager.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in White Plains, NY
pros: Benefits are very competitive, staff start off with 4 weeks PTO, as well as holiday time and personal time off, with ability to earn a 5th week of PTO after several years. Hospital is very focused on continuing education, they encourage and pay for CMEs, they offer tuition reimbursement, pay for board certification. Salary is exceptional, especially compared to Westchester hospitals.
cons: Staffing tends to be substandard and can feel short often. Half the hospital campuses are union, whereas the other half is not, though unclear how this affects benefits, staffing, salary, etc. Leadership and management are more focused on budgetary needs than staff and patient care.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: core values are great, advancement and learning opportunities, multiple campuses to work, great pay and benefits, involved managers,
cons: Political, change is slow, outdated practices in some units, union hospital that makes seasoned nurses untouchable , poor follow up on issues affecting employees , makes certification difficult for some areas , clinical ladder advancement is difficult to achieve .

job_title: Medical Technologist in New York, NY
pros: Easy training for the job, decent pay at $26.29/hr
cons: No job advancement or salary raises. Co-workers are terrible, ie, they are envious or hateful for no reason except that you're new; they start trouble by blaming you for breaking the machine or releasing a lab result without checking for potential errors. so immediately they go straight to the supervisor or director without telling you what had happen and you get pull into the office for questioning. supervisors are even worse because of favoritism and their general stupidity for not knowing how things work but get hired because they have experience in work years regardless of the type of work they did. and for managers, they need to go to b-school and get some training.

job_title: Pharmacy Technician in New York, NY
pros: I remember when I first applied to nyp. I was  turned down but was always told to keep trying. So I did. And I have never been happier. I was welcomed with open arms and trained with patience and persistence and when ever I have a rough day I have a great team that reminds me to keep going.
cons: I have no cons about hospital.

review_title: Overall positive work experience. Ideal fit for someone interested in good work-life balance, traditional role, minimally challenging position.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Good work-life balance, health insurance, and generous PTO. Good reputation in NY and across the nation.
cons: Older and rigid corporate culture in terms of hierarchy, processes, structure, manager-employee role.  Pay below market rate. No continuing education for non-clinical positions.  New ideas and challenges not recognized - driven only by management. No 401k match.

job_title: Senior IT Developer in New York, NY
pros: NYPH provides IT developers the appropriate work and life balance which allows for better utilization of efforts in accomplishing amazing implementations of technology to health care over the past decade. With ever changing IT technology, IT developers like myself are constantly challenged and rewarded with job stability and future growth.
cons: Working at NYPH requires working with various departments that don't sometimes need to more convincing in using latest technology and innovations. Some departments need additional time to take advantage of the IT's latest innovations. Patients deserve these benefits sooner than later. IT staff need to be patient with these departments.

job_title: Nursing Attendant in New York, NY
pros: Flexible with scheduling as a part-time, great benefits through the union, free uniforms, technologically advanced, prestigious place to work
cons:
Only one day of orientation!! 

Very understaffed, I would be the only Nursing Attendant to the units (floated) taking a million vitals, weights, I&O and doing so many cares and answering call bells all by myself, lucky if the nurses helped.  Different units have different procedures super frustrating to have to readjust overtime.

Horrible parking and the lots are expensive

job_title: Data Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Amazing patient care, great benefits. Outstanding opportunity that was given to me years ago. I defensively learned a lot. The focus is patient reserved always they really care about thbe well-being and satisfaction of the patients
cons: There is very little opportunity for growth within departments, you can stay in the same position all your life without being offered or considered for any other roll. Many policy that don't give room for the reality that is life

review_title: Amazing things happen here because it’s an amazing place!
job_title: Executive in New York, NY
pros: Cutting edge medicine, committed and visible leadership, the organization cares and focuses on culture, fantastic learning opportunities delivered to the organization (classes, HMM, elearning) , lots of ways to be recognized and a focus on recognition,  compassionate people work here and are committed to the mission.
cons: Facilities need to be updated , need more competitive pay and bonuses, need to be more progressive around telecommuting at alll levels

job_title: Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, that's about it.
cons: The good benefits are not worth the misery of working there. Too many layers of leadership. Very cut throat, vicious environment. Toxic place.  No working from home. Too many strict rules. Feels more like prison. You're monitored for when you come in, when you leave to lunch, when you get back, what time you leave, what you're wearing. No one can send an email to just you, everyone along the chain of command must be copied on emails. Just makes you feel very uncomfortable, like you're walking on eggshells. The women there are extremely catty and clique-ish and anyone there will throw you under the bus in a heartbeat to make themselves look good. It's all about power and status there. No actual teamwork. I left as fast as I could.

review_title: Software Developer - Comfortable place to work
job_title: Technology Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
- Every person on my team is genuinely a nice person! It makes the work environment very comfortable. 

- You can work from home a few times a week.

- The main administrative office is at 466 Lexington Ave, right next to Grand Central. So this is very easy for people to commute to either by subway, bus, Metro-North, or bike. Open floor plan :( but the offices are clean and nice. 

- Managers are very helpful and encouraging if you want to go to graduate school. $7500 for tuition reimbursement or more if the degree is healthcare related.

- My management is receptive to new ideas and technologies within our group.
cons:
- The hiring process was the worst experience I have ever encountered at any company. The internal recruiter gave me wrong information in regards to my position, start date, compensation, etc. I had to reach out to the Vice President of my department several times when the recruiter kept ignoring my voicemails and emails. My VP would then reach out to one of the VPs of HR, and then I would receive a phone call immediately from the recruiter I was dealing with. This happened a few times. I honestly almost decided not to join just because how atrocious this process was, but I liked the managers, the people, and the work so I ultimately decided to follow through. Many of my fellow employees who were hired the same year as me encountered the same difficulties, especially with the same recruiter I had to deal with. My team now attempts to hire directly with potential employees until it's absolutely necessary to bring in HR. 

- There are so many useful technologies and applications that NYP software developers could build in-house, but management usually goes with bug ridden 3rd-party technology. The data that is available is so useful, and could help patients and the hospital! 

Minor things: 
-------------------
- Hospital bureaucracy can been somewhat difficult to work with at times. Anything involving money requires several layers/departments of approval. More so than other companies. 

- The technologies and medical processes need to be improved and standardized. There are attempts at this currently ongoing, so hopefully in a couple years things will be better.

- A minor nitpick but the internal job titles are sometimes different than what is listed on the job listing in the careers section.

review_title: Where physician's happiness comes after the secretary's
job_title: Physician Fellow in New York, NY
pros: This is an amazing hospital with excellent clinical work and research productivity. You will be surrounded by driven physicians who also must deal with the same instiutional barriers to effective clinical care. Therefore there is a sense of solidarity.
cons: This place is incredibly difficult to work due to the non-streamlined nature. There is incredible bureaucracy, laziness by all the ancillary staff (including nurses, schedulers, etc) and the onus therefore falls on the residents, fellows and medical students to pick up all the slack.

job_title: Clinical Laboratory Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Pros - good benefits (union position), good vacation time, decent schedule (if you can get a day job)
cons: Upper management is very accusatory, and the blame game is very common. High stress environment in the lab and the workload is overbearing. Some employees get preferential treatment because they are friendly with management. Overall do NOT recommend this at a place to stay long-term.

review_title: A big name hospital that succumbs to the culture of corrupt corporations
job_title: Clinical Nurse in New York, NY
pros: NYP Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital is one of the best children's hospitals in the country. I grew as a person and as a nurse and I owe it all to the bedside nurses I worked with. I owe none of my personal or professional growth to any of the 4 nurse managers I had in the 4 years I was an employee. I think CHONY utilizes the most modern approaches to Pediatric Intensive Care and many of our patients have good outcomes. The patient population is varied and it is rewarding to be able to care for critically ill children and make a true difference in their lives.
cons: Oh boy...let's start with management. There is HIGH turnover for management in pediatric intensive care, which is bad. In the 4 years I was there I had 4 managers. During my tenure in the PICU, we were constantly short-staffed. NYSNA couldn't help us, and upper level management would placate us by giving us free breakfast and pretending like they understood our concerns. When various directors and VPs came to the PICU to answer our questions, they responded like politicians with no clear answers. While we were severely short-staffed, management turned some random corners of our unit into bed spaces. We added about 4 more bed-spaces without adding anymore nurses. The unit spent so much money paying overtime. It doesn't take a genius to figure out pediatric units across the county generally don't make money, and this is why unit budgets are so restrictive.  Inter-unit relations were also strained because of a lack of middle management (because there quite literally was no manager) When I worked there, senior level nursing leaders began to take the first steps towards achieving Magnet status. I knew the hospital had no chance of achieving this prestigious status based on my personal observations, and the grievances of my colleagues who worked in other adult & pediatric units. Please don't let the guise of NYP being a hospital fool you. They are a big business in which their various chief executives receive annual bonuses of $1 million+. Everything comes down to money. If it doesn't make money, don't throw money at it.

review_title: Great place to work and grow
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Excellent pay and benefits. They are making strides in work-life balance. They treat their nurses well and try to listen and incorporate feedback.
cons: I call my job the golden prison. They make it so good it's hard to leave. The educational benefits, the health benefits, the pay, the work environment, it's all excellent. The commute if you live outside the city? Not so much.

job_title: Nurse Clinician in New York, NY
pros:
Great Teamwork at Unit Level as well as interactions with other teams
Fair working environment, our department values nursing and nursing role and impact, hence we are on our way to becoming a Magnet Designated Campus
cons: At the present time I do not see any true cons, I would like to see improved transition to retirement bridging of benefits at a more affordable rate, for the future.

job_title: Practice Manager in New York, NY
pros: Vast system that has lots of resources, but work community can only be found at the practice level. This hospital system is very good at extraordinary medical care, but is lacking at dealing with the basics.
cons: A matrixed organization that has 4 different organizational cultures, NYP/Cornell, NYP/ Columbia, Weill Cornell Medical College Physician Organization and Columbia Doctors Faculty Practice. There are other campuses, but Cornell and Columbia define the two major organizational cultures.

review_title: NYP is a great place to be a nurse, I have worked here since 2002 and love the hospital and the people.
job_title: Staff Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Pay, work environment the staff is wonderful honestly throughout the whole hospital the people are great and you tend to feel proud to work there
cons:
Staffing pay rate, no union so no weekend and evening differentials which would make an enormous difference 
Staffing can be a crunch and I don’t think it should be

job_title: IT Project Manager in New York, NY
pros:
OK salary
Good benefits (except beware they are a self-insured employer - look it up it really matters)
Projects are interesting
Generally the people you work with are really committed to making a difference
cons:
Forget moving up unless you are part of the 'club'
HR doesn't even respond to internal employees applying to internal postings
Upper management is very closed and politics abound

review_title: Amazing Hospital, not so Amazing Talent Acquisition Team.
job_title: Soon to BE Former Employee in New York, NY
pros: Unlimited resources here at the Columbia campus, a team that goes above and beyond to see that the needs of the patients are achieved. Great culture and values that permeates the campus. After working here for almost 6 yrs I can say the positive attitudes of my coworkers are infectious and I love coming to work everyday, knowing that I am surrounded by a team that truly cares about you and the well-being of the patients.
cons:
#1 If you don't live close the commute can be really difficult. My commute was typically on average 3.5hrs a day in total. 
The number #2 and most important Con to working here and the reason I will not advise any of my friends or family to work here is because of the horrible Job that's done by "The Talent Acquisition Team." The job of Talent Acquisition is to not only find the best external talent but also with recommendation of management find and develop internal talent also across every department. I must say its disheartening, when you apply for an internal position and you don't even get a response saying you have not been accepted or a reason for not being accepted and ultimately your resume just gets thrown into a basket of undesirables. This goes for myself and fellow colleagues who are routinely ignored during the hiring process.

As an exemplary worker, who receives outstanding employee evaluations and one who actually took advantage of the outstanding employee education benefits that Columbia offers, was able to achieve a Masters degree in Public Administration. After acquiring my degree and applying to countless open leadership positions I was unable to receive not one invitation for an interview!!! However, many circumvent the submission process and are  granted interviews. Those positions are routinely filled based on who you know, rather than what you know. 
Ultimately I became so Jaded by the action or lack of action from  Talent Acquisition at Presbyterian Columbia,  that  I am no longer interested in any positions at this institution. On the bright side, I was offered an amazing position at another outstanding Medical institution in the New York City Area which I accepted.  I am currently enjoying my last few weeks at this fine institution, I will truly miss being apart of an organisation that helped mold me to become the person I am today.

job_title: PSR in White Plains, NY
pros: Provides supervision for the LCAT, encourages continued education and growth, positive work environment, never boring, good pay, great department, quality patient care
cons: It can be hard to get your documentation done during the day. For this position I think it would be better to work on salary and not by the hour. Not all disciplines want to run groups but it is part of your job to make it happen.  There is a lot of leading without authority. Not all staff understand or realize the clinical nature of the work you do and may see it as just "recreation"

job_title: Vice President/Cno in New York, NY
pros: Our  CEO is amazing! He champions people - staff, patients and families. He takes care of us, so we can take better care of our patients and their families.  He champions health care for all, while trying to drive up quality and drive down cost. He invests money in infrastructuon and  innovation to keep us cutting edge into the future.  I’d follow him anywhere!
cons: I cannot think of any at this time. I’ve worked in several health care organizations, and I keep pinching myself since arriving at NYP. Amazing place! Amazing people!

job_title: in New York, NY
pros:
If you work on the clinical side, things are great.
Great reputation - number 6 in the country - number 1 in NY.
Benefits and paid time off are great.
cons:
A lot of politics in my office. People that have been there awhile treat others terribly and are very inflexible.  Cliquey and catty is the best way to describe it - we are supposed to be a team.
Managers don't always stick up for their employees - concerned with image.
I work a lot of long hours and am not compensated appropriately.

review_title: Web site designer, developer, and project lead
job_title: IS Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great working atmosphere, and team to work with on a daily basis. The opportunity to work on leading edge technology and provide that to meaningful use in society helping hospital patients needing medical care.
cons: They lack a formal training program for Information Technology and Information Services professionals. This is needed for building better technology by training today's employees who are interested in learning and willing to contribute in other areas of the workplace.

job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Health benefits
Vacation time
Job security
cons: Salary is not based on scope of job , experience and education.  It's who you know and other factors ( read between the lines). Leadership tends ask a lot from  employees and we get nothing in return.

review_title: Great place to work every team member contributes to credo of respect
job_title: Security in New York, NY
pros: From our Senior Leadership to the staff everyone is on the same page in regards to treating everyone with kindness courtesy and empathy
cons: There are no downsides it is a great place to work

review_title: Very demanding and rewarding place to work
job_title: IT Manager in New York, NY
pros: IT department is very lean and doing great job with very limited resources. Be ready to work hard and also be ready for constant flow of requests and projects, some of them are the most exciting projects in Healthcare IT.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Prestigious Name. Great Supportive Services.

This place has a truly corrupt management and needs to be re-structured from the top down.  Management is scary and is threatened by hardworking, dedicated nurses that are smarter, willing to work harder, and willing to open their mouths when they see a problem.

job_title: Staff Accountant in New York, NY
pros: Benefits are amazing. You'll never find benefits this good at another job. People are cool to work with. Overall more laid back culture than you'd find at a profit hungry company. Also a gigantic hospital with endless opportunities. Largest private employer in NYC.
cons: No glaring cons. Some people say pay. But when you factor in the benefits, the total compensation more than makes up for the still competitive wages in my opinion.

job_title: Physician Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Good team of PAs. Large facility

Upper management does not care about our compensation or work conditions. This hospital pays less than the other 2 hospitals within a 2 block radius, and this has been the case for years. NYP always seems to be behind in increasing our salary/hourly wage. They expect you to work at the highest standard of care but refuse to support and help you achieve that. 

To them, PAs are just bodies to fill spaces. They don't care about loyalty here; even if you've worked 12 years for them they will easily let you go if you aren't a "yes" man.

review_title: A Mix of Good and Bad, On the right path
job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: They have built a brand that upholds itself to high standards and try to encourage staff to continue to educate and hold positions that develops a nurse.
cons: They took over my hospital so I believe there is probably a large difference in my hospital compared to Weill Cornell or the main NYP hospitals, but it seems that you're a very small person in this large organization that cares more about its numbers and performance and patients, but less about its staff.

review_title: Great company to work for, for life
job_title: Or RN in New York, NY
pros: Environment is encouraging, positive. Coworkers are nice, pay is good and great vacation time for nurses. Management is great too.

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: One of the main reason NYP is one of the best place to work is due to the diversity of the employees. Employees are treated with respect, genuine input is always encouraged. Employees are treated fairly and good relations are encouraged. Learning and Training are strongly encouraged.
cons: New York Presbyterian is a wonderful place to work when you put in the work you reap the rewards.

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Some of the most unique working environments where you can be working alongside some of the top minds in Healthcare and Medical Education.
cons: Non-profit means no profit sharing. 403b plan is not matched by the company.

review_title: Great care, great people, improving culture
job_title: Quality and Patient Safety in New York, NY

review_title: The job requires a lot of hard work but we have a very supportive management.
job_title: Clinical Nurse I in New York, NY

job_title: Senior Physical Therapist in New York, NY

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: you are well compensated for what you do.  they are will spend what it takes to get you in the door.  vacation time is also generous.
cons: You will get very little support from middle mgt.  You will need to CYA at all time.  They will always ask what have you done lately.  They do not provide growth.  Senior mgt and very territorial.

job_title: Staff RN in New York, NY
pros: Competitive pay and benefits. A lot of exposure to illnesses/ surgeries that you would not see in other hospital settings.
cons: Bad morale. Everyone only out for themselves. New staff thrown into situations without proper training. Upper management is not aware of the problems going on below them. Good workers work hard, bad workers reap the benefits without having to work as hard or at all. At best- organized chaos.

review_title: Loved the job.  Lots of deceit

review_title: Overall a very nice place to work.

job_title: Analyst in New York, NY

review_title: (Mostly) good colleagues, management too focused on bottom line
job_title: Staff RN in Cortlandt Manor, NY

job_title: HVAC Controls Coordinator in Brooklyn, NY

Great place to work at. Good people, good culture, flexible schedule.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Great pay and opportunity to grow in your career

job_title: Dietary Worker in Flushing, NY
pros: Working at New York Presbyterian has been an amazing experience. It's a good job to have throughout college because they work with your schedule and make it able for you to do both of you have to. Also they are willing to work with you if you would like to get some extra hours here and there.

review_title: large organization, decent benefits, powerful leadership team (both good and bad)

job_title: Unit Clerk in New York, NY

job_title: Pharmacy Technician in New York, NY

review_title: Decent Employer for Per Diem Paramedic

job_title: Clinical Staff in New York, NY

job_title: OR Technician in New York, NY

review_title: NYP treats their employees like gold

pros:

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Salary goes into the bank every 2 weeks.
If you stick around long enough (a few years), chances are you'll get promoted (like many in upper management): not because you're good, but because you outlived all the good ones who were so frustrated and left.
cons:
The institution is SOLELY process driven -- it's about documenting, going to meetings, and writing "action items". A lot of talk, very little work gets done. Something didn't get done? No problem! Just make up an artificial sub-action-item and put a tick next to it. In reality, did anything improve? No, but the PERCEPTION of it did ("yay, we made some progress").  This is a very frustrating place to work for. People are there just to draw a salary. 
Do not expect to be challenged, heard, or respected. Everything is delegated to vendors, nothing gets done in house (therefore, everyone is some sort of a "manager" -- big titles, no experience or real input). 
Management is delusional because it actually thinks it's at the cutting edge. 2012: "lets use Twitter! Not sure how, but at least we can say that we are using it." 
I've spoken to nurses, doctors, and admin people who worked elsewhere: things are better at small, less prestigious institutions. NYP is riding Columbia's reputation of excellence. Unfortunately it seems like the only "AMAZING" thing that is happening at NYP is that somehow the doctors still function and maintain a good reputation for the organization.... Believe me, I am not the only one who shares this sentiment....

job_title: Attending Physician (Hospitalist) in Flushing, NY
pros: Good location, Lots of pathology - this is about it.
cons:
STAY AWAY FROM THIS PLACE like the plague. Unless you are desperate for a job, I would never want to work here EVER again. what may seem at first a charming to-be boss, seems very easy going and supportive. But once you are in, it all turns into something that is more than meets the eye. There is a mass exodus from this place for a reason. All the physicians are running away faster than can be hire. That is why positions keeps opening up.

If you want a coffee, get ready to be yelled at. If you get caught surfing the web, get ready to be yelled at. If you need a personal day, get ready to get coverage by yourself or be yelled at. If you are pregnant and need an ultrasound, be prepared to be asked to submit your resignation/get yelled at/beg for a personal day. You want to plan a vacation? Well be prepared cuz it wont be approve unless its the day of as the schedule is never ready nor ahead of time. The schedule is out the day prior so nobody ever knows whats going on -- you will be place you on days, nights, swing hours - all over the place...cuz you know why? nobody will be able to do anything about it.

The whole team is being worked like dogs to cover any and all services to the point of sweatshop work. Get ready to do 18-25 admissions in inpatient and observation unit ALL BY YOURSELF! You're tough and you can handle it right? - WRONG, cuz here, you have no supporting ancillary staff! Get ready to transport pts by urself! Get ready to put IVs in yourself! Get ready to be harassed by nursing staff as you ARE AN INTERN! you will not feel as if you are an attending! why you ask? because of the top down culture which makes the hospitalist a...sadly to say "everyone's intern"

If you need a job & money to pay the bills...go for the job, but you will see within 1 month of working here that it will be the biggest mistake of your life. You can pretty much work anywhere for prob a bit tad lower salary and have a trillion times better work life balance. 
BE WARNED!

Dont believe me? Go in for an interview and ask the above questions to any of the other hospitalist working there right now and the best question to ask anyone of them is..."when are you leaving"...
